content.body: hahahahaha.

from the article: "The whole thing is supposed to be of help to deaf-blind people, who were never surveyed for their preferences, an action I recommended to WAI at a face-to-face meeting in 2003. Nor was any user testing carried out. (That’s all I can tell from published evidence, anyway. I sent e-mail inquiries to deaf-blind organizations in several countries asking if they’d been surveyed or had any opinions, with no response.)"
that certainly helps to put the whole issue in perspectice, if they have a history of doing no research
*perspective
indeed.
The poll appears
Shelley's links are interesting, considering summary has been rejected DH5 (maybe even DH6) over and over and over...
Dashiva: You meant "The poll dancing appears."
Also interesting that Roy thinks summary will be required by government when existing government advice actually discourages it...
that government advice was cited by the wai as an example of why we had to keep summary=""
i'd never seen it before then
i think the wai may have assumed i don't read links they sent me
especially long documents like that
Maybe someone should link it to Roy too, then
Dashiva: Do you have a list of where it is discouraged? and where it is encouraged? (government wise)
karlcow: The one mentioned earlier is at http://www.access-board.gov/sec508/guide/1194.22.htm#(i) -- scroll one paragraph up
http://www.coi.gov.uk/guidance.php?page=137
recommends http://webaim.org/techniques/tables/data.php
which says http://webaim.org/techniques/tables/data.php#summaries
so UK seems to say follow wcag
from http://www.coi.gov.uk/guidance.php?page=188
It's a shame, that summary there would be useful for us poor normal folks too
troll
Hah
That's one of the points that's been made so many times. Summaries often contain non-structural information that's useful to all users, not just disabled ones
French Gov recommends WCAG 2.0 un WCAG 1.0 http://www.references.modernisation.gouv.fr/rgaa-accessibilite
everyone says to follow wcag
wcag is wrong
It's easy to think that way if you're stuck in handicap parking analogies, I suppose. There you have to steal spaces from normal users.
But information can be made available for everyone, so let's not be mean.
And now, for my next trick, I will not be late for my flight. *poof* :)
not only is it wrong, but the people who wrote it are unwilling to listen to criticism on how it is wrong
this has been amply demonstrated for many years
most recently (though by no means exclusively) by their refusal to respond to hixie's direct feedback
Canada too  http://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/clf2-nsi2/clfs-nnsi/clfs-nnsi-2-fra.asp
where it is not wrong, it is merely inadequate
(c.f. their techniques document on using the image @alt attribute)
(which cites a grand total of 2 examples, both trivial)

mpilgrim: I was just trying to see if Dashiva's assertion was true or not "[23:01]  <Dashiva> Also interesting that Roy thinks summary will be required by government when existing government advice actually discourages it..."
major changes were made from wcag 1
at the behest of major stakeholders like ibm
e.g. pages requiring javascript are now a-ok
(technically the priority level was dropped from 1 to 2 or some such nonsense. i forget how they phrased it.)
it was EXTREMELY IMPORTANT for ibm that wcag 2 change this requirement
since they have major "web" products like lotus workplace which are entirely javascript
:) a big co influencing a spec… hmmm how surprising… that would be really the first time… never seen that in html 5. <sacarsm/>
(i put "web" in scare quotes since there's nothing "webby" about them except that they happen to run in some browsers)
my point is, that's the kind of "feedback" that went into wcag 2
not anything lofty like john (and now sam (and now roy)) seem to assume
research?
user testing?
seriously?
don't make me laugh
making you laugh… now, that would be vulgar :) I beg not.
i guarantee you there was ZERO discussion of the summary attribute
it was just a given
somebody had a bad idea in like 1997 or 1998
to add a summary attribute to tables
they got it into the spec, in a wave of "let's make html more accessible" guilt
from there, it got laundered through WAI and WCAG
and now it's a highly polished turd being offered up and the be-all and end-all of accessibility techniques
and no one is allowed to question it because it came from "experts"
who *surely* must have researched it at least a little bit
instead of just regurgitating the same bad advice for 10 years
and people wonder why accessibility is such a clusterfuck
and in clusterfuck, there is cluster. yeeehaaa
ignore *!*@*.la-grange.net
arf
meanwhile, i'm shocked - SHOCKED! - to discover that roy fielding thinks that appeals to authority are a valid part of technical discourse
truly shocked
"sampling is irrelevant within the context of HTML that is required by law or regulation to be accessible to sight-impaired users."
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Aug/0136.html
you can't argue with logic like that!
heh
re-reading "to hell with wcag 2" 3 years later is great fun
i remember this complaint when it was made: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/w3c-wai-gl/2006AprJun/0184.html
w/followup here: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/w3c-wai-gl/2006AprJun/0397.html
hmm a survey for accessibility http://archive.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/e-government/resources/eaccessibility/content.asp
and http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/w3c-wai-gl/2006JulSep/0000.html
i met her (well, was briefly introduced) once at csun
remarkable woman
can't remember her own phone number
(or so i was told)
but contributes to complex standards for years on end
of course, wcag 2 is still incomprehensible to people with cognitive disabilities
and still says nothing useful about how to make your own content accessible to such an audience

anyone got any suggested UI for how to indicate that the changes have been saved once you click "save" on http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/edit-section.html?section=the-code-element ?
hm, nevermind
Hixie: I can't be bothered to comment on the list, but I think that having a way to reach all browsing contexts in the same origin is probably also a security hole.
even if we had background pages (which i like fwiw), we couldn't allow them to just reach all origins, there'd have to be a mechanism where pages opt inot being part of the set.
sorry, I mean that we couldn't allow them to just reach all contexts in the same origin.
http://www.w3.org/TR/WD-html40-970917/struct/tables.html#h-12.1.1

"The TABLE element contains all other elements that specify caption, rows, content, and formatting. Authors should use the title attribute to provide a summary of the table for non-visual user agents, covering its purpose and structure."

"Note. A new attribute for the table summary is needed because the caption for visual users is generally insufficient. The title attribute is inappropriate because browsers render this as a "tool tip" which is limited to a single line of text. In some user agents, long lines are clipped."
this is the sum total of the "research" done on the table summary attribute
the summary attribute first appeared in the 1997-09-17 working draft of html 4
it is not present in the previous draft from 1997-07-08 ( http://www.w3.org/TR/WD-html40-970708/ )
i can find no discussion of it in the www-html mailing list archives for 1997
or 1996, for that matter
it was invented because browsers clipped tooltips
if browsers had supported multiline tooltips, we never would have had a summary attribute
I'm completely shocked. Oh, wait.

quote of the day (from http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-html/1997Jul/0066.html ): "Deprecating a tag doesn't make it obsolete right away, but clearly indicates that there is a 'better' (or at least, more consistent) way of doing things. Any deprecated elements in HTML4.0 won't be obsolete until HTML5.0, probably - and even then they may still be included."

and the followup ( from http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-html/1997Jul/0068.html ): "Nobody ever said that deprecated elements will no longer be supported by browser vendors. For sure I've never heard anybody part of the HTML WG say something like this. Quite on the contrary!"
zcorpan: I'm preparing validator.nu for a system update and reboot. I'll deal with microsyntaxes when it reboots. html5.validator.nu will follow if everything goes well.
hsivonen: there are a couple of other minor fixes I checked in since the last v.nu deployment. Just schema tweaks, and tested
is the Kronos stuff something anyone can GET without cookies or HTTP auth?
is annoyed at a WG Note from the WAI being treated as normative over REC track process
it's kind of surprising to know it is just a Note
annevk2: as far as I can tell, the XML Core WG didn't agree with i18n but added a well-formedness-neutral document conformance req that has no effect on processor behavior
someone should make a scientific analysis of who actually practices the handling-people bible on public-html
hsivonen, I mean that i18n agreed with the compromise
meant*
annevk2: ok
MikeSmith: OK. I'll do a full redeployment after reboot
hsivonen: while you're at it, quick question -
http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=631
the current datatype-checking code doesn't make sure that the value of the iframe name attribute is more than one character
(I'll wait until DNS updates before I start the updatie process)
hsivonen: but the spec says, "A valid browsing context name is any string with at least one
character that does not start with a U+005F LOW LINE character."
MikeSmith: looks like a genuine bug
OK, I'll make a patch for it
in the datatype lib that is
yeah, i'll take a look
one other open one that came up recently was this:
Product:
Component:
Status: NEW
Resolution:
Assigned To: Henri Sivonen <hsivonen⊙if>
Hardware:
oops
http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=591
IETF process is apparently not very shiny: http://www.0xdeadbeef.com/weblog/?p=1346&cpage=1#comment-206483
hsivonen: need to also report an error if an XML document that has a <meta charset='utf-8'/> is not actually encoded in UTF-8.
MikeSmith: I think what's needed is an extension to the ValidationContext API (a ValidationContext2 interface on the same object) that allows datatypes acquire the Locator object
then the Locator object should implement Locator2 which, IIRC, exposes the encoding
and then the parsers need to implement Locator2
and then datatyping that is sensitive to the encoding becomes possible
there's an open Jing bug about this
ah, OK
Foo2 interfaces suck, but they are the most compatible way of doing this without breaking the use of the datatype lib with old versions of Jing and MSV
I see
Foo2 feels COMtaminated
heh
hsivonen: so for now, maybe one thing worth considering is to add an Info message saying, "<meta charset="utf-8"/> found in XML document. Make sure your document is actually encoded in UTF-8."
or a Warning
can't add it in the assertions-checking code because of the problem of schematron only being able to emit errors
not if you want to keep the Java assertions code in sync with the assertions.sch file
hsivonen: hmm, maybe it's something I could add to the proposed warnings.sch
oh
can't do that either because I have no way of knowing at the point it the document is XML or text/html
困った
I guess I could simply implement what I said above on the V.nu branch of Jing and not wait for the trunk
hsivonen: btw, I looked at the build stuff in the jing trunk for generating the gcj binary
I don't know who came up with that stuff, but it seems way overcomplicated
MikeSmith: the Java build process for Jing trunk is complicated, too
well, the gcj thing has the additional disadvantage of being broken
woohoo! Locator2 is in JDK 5
well, that's a bright spot, at least
hsivonen: anyway, that gcj build uses hard-coded path names all over the place, and the paths it's pointing to seem to have moved since the time the build setup was written
the gcj/dist file
It's just a shell script
I don't know if that's some kind of standard RPM thing or what, but it's just absolutely arcane
in contrast to the build setup for the debian trang package
which just uses a simple Makefile
hsivonen: so, anyway, what I'm getting at is, I'm going to try to make a non-broken gcj build for jing
and if I can get it to work, I'll send a patch and if it looks OK, maybe you can talk with James and George about committing it to the trunk in place of that thing that's there now
seems like a good plan
OK

I didn't add support to the HTML parser yet
hsivonen: excellent
I checked in the browsing-context-name fix, with your wording change
MikeSmith: thanks

hsivonen: I guess I should check out the validator-nu branch instead of the trunk

org.relaxng.datatype thing

annevk2: not sure if it's worth noting in the diff doc, but the restriction in HTML5 that the target attribute and iframe name attribute must be at least one character is a change vs HTML4
in HTML4, it's just CDATA, with no further restrictions stated in the spec
we made a lot of those things more strict
(and some more loose, e.g. id)
e.g. accept-charset was CDATA in HTML4
should I note it is now actually usefully checked?
it seemed too much effort
Would anyone specify an empty name for any reason other than spec lawyering?
one would think someone in California had figured out how to protect disk against minor earthquakes
hsivonen: Multiple redundant data centers :P
Dashiva: I have deduntant disks, but these artificial earthquakes affect both disks at the same time
getting multilocation personal data centers is expensive
I don't recall the exact value, but it's something like at least 300 miles apart from each other
I can't think of any home-grown solutions that both absorb shocks properly and don't have extra vibrations afterwards
https://twitter.com/roessler/statuses/3120872586
that quote never gets old, does it? :)
There was an ALA article about "unwebbable" content a while ago. One of the examples [in a comment] was poetry, which "In fact, this is text that deliberately defies conventions and structure."
Doesn't that imply adding syntax for poetry is by definition an impossible task?
You could use unconventional, unstructured syntax
Or you could say your syntax defies defiance of conventions and structure
But when you put it into a spec, you're a sellout
Nobody will want your syntax anymore
is the original text of http://html5.digitalbazaar.com/a-new-way-forward/ archived somewhere?
hsivonen: I have a copy on my HD
the "About the Author" bit is interesting

annevk2: it's probably not worth the effort to list them individually, but maybe adding a general statement that "a number of attributes values now how further restrictions; for example, some values that were allowed to be empty in HTML4 are not allowed to be empty in HTML5, ..."

hmm. "Problem: No Way for Experts to Contribute in a Meaningful Way"

it takes CDATA instead though to sucky DTDs
I think that when you are making a serious document posting links to last week and (less so) the CSS Squirrel does not advance your credibility
s/advance/help/

annevk2: I'm confused by " the intent of accesskey in HTML5 was to take a single character"
yeah, 4
and also s/though/due/

hsivonen: so I realize now that v.nu schema and datatype library have have both a "positive integer" and "non-negative integer" datatype
but the spec has only "non-negative integer"
Does it have something like "non-zero non-negative integer"?
(which is basically positive, for people who aren't sure what positive means)
Yeah, I remember that being wrangled out :)
MikeSmith: IIRC, the spec has places where a non-negative integer isn't allowed to be zzero
ah, OK
I'll look more closely
IIRC, Hixie doesn't trust readers to understand what a positive integer is
heh
"Roman era integer"
Dashiva: Can you mark "Roman era" up with a time element so I know what you mean?
We should call them "optimistic integers"
gsnedders|work: It's before 1592 (or whenever it was)
Do what proper mathematicians do, and use ℕ instead of fuzzy words like "integer", so there's no ambiguity
MikeSmith, DOM attributes can be limited to only positive non-zero numbers :)
annevk2: yeah, I saw that in the spec, but in this case was just referring to restrictions on content attributes.
conformance on attributes seems to be phrased like "valid non-negative integer greater than zero"
yeah
Makes me wonder why we bother with the non-negative part
Dashiva: use the comment box in the spec
Because you might have a negative integer greater than zero.
annevk2: in the v.nu schema, it's actually a different datatype. which makes sense
A really-complex number.
zcorpan: The barrier of entry is too high (I'd have to load the spec)
zero is an integer, just not a positive integer
(Because complex numbers aren't enough)
Dashiva: load the multipage version
zcorpan: You getting t-shirts made?
zcorpan: That means starting a web browser.
zcorpan: It still requires me to switch to a browser
Dashiva: use opera for irc, then you don't need to switch to another app
How about... no
gsnedders|work: (Actually they are enough for most purposes, which is why we still use complex numbers instead of anything fancier)
zcorpan: But I'd still have to change tab!
Dashiva: use curl
I'm using IRC
notes he is somewhat amused that three of the people in this conversation are in one room
maybe we should have an irc bot for filing spec comments
One of you young'uns with this newfangled 'superhighway' stuff can submit for me
waves cane
MikeSmith, yeah, maybe file a bug?
Dashiva: I could paste the spec in a /msg to you
gsnedders|work: I'm in one room too
Philip`: How do I request external resources in /msg?
Hixie: please write an irc bot for filing spec comments so that people don't have to load the spec to file comments
MikeSmith, I'd agree that having all the _actual_ datatypes together makes more sense than just having a subset and another set defined in prose
Dashiva: You pipe it, from curl.
Dashiva: You don't, you just ask the person you're messaging to paste it to you
hhttp
Besides, I don't like parsing javascript in my head unless I really have to
Dashiva: you mean you like it when you really have to?
Yeah
It makes me feel useful and accomplished
reaches the thread about making unquoted attributes non-conforming
First year I interned at Opera we got a tiny meeting room for our office since there were no free offices
One day we come in and find a<!--b&&c-->d on the whiteboard and some scribbled comments about "Does this work?"
Tarquin had decided to outsource :)
Dashiva: Serves you right for interning at Opera!
Oh, wait…
It's actually valid JS. Pretty useless, but valid!
Yeah it is
Also it won't be treated as a comment
but <!--b&&c-->d will be
Oh wait, it will be treated as a
as zcorpan just pointed out to me
Yah
(I was confusing the behaviour of <!-- and -->(
Silly old bear
But he's such a lovable old bear, with his long greying hair!
You need to escape your (, jgraham
Dashiva: Not in magic IRC regexp syntax I don't
")I was confusing the behaviour of <!-- and -->("?
zcorpan: Magical IRC regexp matches from the end
Magical irc regexp matches whatever makes the most sense
No, Magical IRC regexp does exactly what you intend it to.
Not even magical IRC regexp is that powerful
gsnedders|work: Not quite otherwise s/// would work for anything
jgraham: see topic
That doesn't work, because it throws E_EMPTY
(for the first argument)
gsnedders|work: Not in any proper regexp implementation, i.e. Perl's
You mean there are other proper regexp implementations?
Javascript's!
Javascript does indeed allow empty regexps
(But not as a literal, since it's treated as a comment)
It just matches all the distinct substrings with length zero, which seems like a perfectly natural and sensible thing to do
(Unless you express it as /(?:)/ which is semantically an empty regexp if not syntactically)
finds, "I will buy lunch for whomever fixes floats so that they work properly." — Hixie, Bugzilla, 2001-04-29

hsivonen: thinking about the microsyntaxes scraping.. the fact that getting those messages current depends stopping and restarting v.nu seems to really cry out for actual API to grab those in real time, and then some kind of simple DB instead
the technical limitations of wikis seem like a big deficiency in this case
or maybe there's some wiki that's capable of storing content as names and values in a db
while still providing a wiki interface
what happened to Google Base?
or maybe there are other things like that around now
or DabbleDB
I believe that if someone writes the software we'll take it
but note that having it on the wiki has advantages; e.g. spam control, accounts are sorted out, etc.

annevk2: I understand all that. But I'd really think there'd be an simple online DB with those same features and almost the same ease of use as a wiki, but with a real rest API for retrieving data from it.
I guess to me the lack of the network API is the real issue
I guess it would be possible to have some kind of thing that scrapes the wiki in real time and exposes an API
that's an interesting idea
but that would really seem suboptimal to me at least
though I guess in this case it's a very small amount of data and the scraping would be very quick
maybe, but wiki's have solved a lot of problems
no argument from me there
accounts, accountability, easy editing, etc.
cronjob that scrapes and exposes a friendly API sounds good to me
(you'd cache the scraped data)
annevk2: yeah, I guess I'll write one unless somebody else beats me to it
Surely putting a wiki-like interface on a key-value document store would not be hard
In fact something like the admin interface to couch-db is already quite close to what you want I think
I guess dabbleDB and Google Base may be too
the other great thing about wikis is having the change history available, and the record of accountability (as annevk2 pointed out)
so whatever other mechanism should provide that at least
git! hg!
the tools will (en)s(l)ave use
*us
Surely you could make a user-editable database with two lines of Ruby/Rails code?
(or Python/Django or whatever)
Philip`: Surely somebody else must have done that already for me so that I don't have to.
Which two lines?
jgraham: import and print
those are statements, not lines
anyway, it's not just having the DB, it's having all the Wiki UI stuff on top of it
change history, etc.
and Ogg Theora videos.
Change history seems like the big one

jgraham: The ones in the tutorial screencasts where you make a user-editable database with two lines of code using the user-editable database scaffolding which conveniently happens to have been written already for precisely this purpose, I guess
Because I guess most k-v stores are designed to be efficient rather than to keep records
MikeSmith: I'd rather deal with rel registry before optimizing microsyntax stuff
is still waiting for DNS for validator.nu to update
I guess I should defer the system update until tomorrow when DNS must have updated

jgraham: you know, for me at least, it really is all about the API. I'd think whatever Wiki could easily have some kind of standard markup for indicating a string on the page that's a key, and whatever chunk of text is its associated value
and then the Wiki's own backend could expose an API for that
We should use RDF for that.
hmm, maybe I'll shut up for now
MikeSmith: The reason I was thinking about couchdb is that the API is really the main thing
what's the backend on the whatwg wiki?
jgraham: OK
The store just serves json
I see
The problem is I don't know how easy it is to add versioning to that
for the rel registry, it could be a GETtable text/plain resource with one registered token on each line and LF line breaks
(well I guess it is rather easy to do it manually by adding a version key to each document)
jgraham: what kind of versioning?
I was thinking of an append-only registry
hsivonen: MikeSmith seems to want wiki-like history which imp[lies storing multiple versions (or diffs or something)
WTF!? https://twitter.com/WHATWG/status/3122997127
virtuelv: http://www.whatwg.org/#updater
(look down the page)
ah
I wonder what happens if I say that everyone can update the twitter account from http://www.whatwg.org/#updater from @whatwg
Guess it's better to wait for Hixie to be around since I think he's the only one with the login details
oh well

I love how Kyle Weems complains about attacking people (in http://www.cssquirrel.com/2009/07/09/comic-update-manners-after-the-xhtmlacolypse/) and then goes on to publish a comic like http://www.cssquirrel.com/comic/?comic=30

I personally just wish that Kyle would into his comics put more depictions of real violence, with some nudity thrown in now and then
or even some sex. I think it was Einstein who said "there are few things in the world that are funnier than depictions of cartoon characters having sex."

OK, where's the drugs and rock and roll?
Couchdb already has revision tracking it seems

investigates
hmm, I guess that's been gone for a long while

does Shift-v jjjd
Creap: yeah

'yeah' as in.. figure is not for decorational images?
we could build something to meet our own needs, and then productize it

figure, in my estimation, is for something that you or somebody else might possibly want to reference by its title
see Figure 1.2 at <url>

oh. now I'm no longer the only one allegedly having personal preferences against RDFa

btw, I'm currently working on a way that will hopefully give us new evidence to work with
so if it doesn't work, we probably just have to vote to decide between people's actual more extreme positions
and if my expectations of the results are met, then it should debunk a lot of the claims about how the new proposals don't "offer the same functionality" as summary=""

Hixie, in the interest of getting the publication of a Working Draft for the heartbeat requirement out of the way and decoupling the resolution of the summary issue from that process, would you be willing to agree to a short term compromise solution, leaving the group to continue debating the details of othermaciej's proposal?

(i've not yet read the 50+ e-mails on the topic)
that's ok, I haven't emailed this to the group yet
Lachy: I am curious what your study is
Hixie: I made a proposal for what I think is a compromise (not sure if that's what Lachy has in mind)

specifically, remove summary from the Obsolete but Conforming features list, and add a big note to The table Element section stating that there has been a proposal to include the summary attribute as conforming, but the issue is not yet decided
Ah, I see he means something different
remove summary="" altogether? i'm certainly very happy to remove summary altogether, yes
so that avoid's John's controversial changes of making summary fully conforming now
that's what i've been askin for forever
yeah, but the difference is the class="XXX" note in the table section that makes it clear the issue is still unresolved
Lachy: you might want to see if John Foliot would buy into that as removing his objection to publishing a WD
we already have an XXX
i'm pretty sure john would object completely to having summary="" be obsolete
yeah, but John is objecting to that since summary is still listed as obsolete, despite the issue still being unresolved
since wai requires use of summary="" in one of their non-normative techniques notes
i thought that's what you were proposing too, making it obsolete completely, not even conforming
I'm not proposing to make it fully obsolete, nor fully conforming. Just a note to say that its in limbo right now

(for the next WD only)

frankly I would be ok with publishing a WD with either Hixie's text or John Foliot's text, my only annoyance is that it's been tied to WD publication when a WD by definition doesn't have to reflect consensus or resolve any specific issue
my doc isn't ready for publication yet. It hasn't been updated in a while and is very out of sync with the spec

also, I was awaiting the resolution for the spec licencing issue before I published it
Lachy: i don't really have any opinion or concern about the heartbeat requirement
furthermore I think periodic WD publication has little meaning except pro forma satisfaction of W3C Process requirements
Lachy: my interest is in addressing the actual issue
which is why I wish we wouldn't mix it up with other things
sure, so is mine. But having the actual issue tied to the publication of a draft is proving harmful. So finding a way to untie it and get on with addressing the actual issue seems productive

that's also why I proposed to to rubys in #html-wg the other day that we simply adopt a process in the group whereby any editor can ask for publication as a WD at any time and it be done without debate.
